section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build children’s own name recognition, sing “The Alphabet Song,” and introduce vocabulary (jealous).
Begin Story Time by introducing the Big Book and asking, What feelings do we have?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Recognize own written name.
Identify emotions in self.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Write children’s names on tags as they watch.
Challenge each child to find the Magnetic Letter that starts his or her name.
Help children trace the first letter of their name.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Find a picture of a child. How does that child feel?
Can you dress up to look brave?
Name some feelings. How many did you name?
Can you draw a picture to show how you feel now?
What could you use to draw or paint a happy face?
Can you find two or three letters that are in your name?
Can you use blocks to build a happy monster?

TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.Photo © Anton Starikov/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder Talk About Your Feelings and introduce related vocabulary (help, frustrated).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to My Big Feelings.
Read closely and talk about the feelings discussed in the the five tales.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Identify emotions in self.
Engage in conflict resolution.
Understand and use a growing number of words that communicate feelings, needs, and wants.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children create a paper-plate face that shows an emotion.
Ask children to present their faces and use a sentence frame to tell how they feel and why.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Show me a picture of a child. Can you use your face to show how the child feels?
Can you act out how you and a friend can share one toy?
What materials in the center do you like to play with? Which ones make you happy?
Can you draw a time when you shared with a friend?
Show me how you would feel if your friend had something you want to have. What will you say to them?
Can you use art supplies or shaving cream to make the first letter in your name?
What are you building? Did you get frustrated while you were building it?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. My BIG Feelings: In Five Small Tales by Sidney Hall, illustrated by Laura Watson. Copyright © 2018 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: paper plates (Food Travel Stockforlife), school supplies (Aleksey Sagitov).

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to develop comprehension skills, engage children with movement, and introduce vocabulary (excited).
Begin Story Time by revisiting My Big Feelings and asking the guiding question, Which words name feelings?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Recognize own written name.
Identify emotions in self.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Discuss how people might show their feeling of excitement.
Have children locate their names and post them above the picture that best reflects how they show excitement.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Look through books to find pictures of people who are showing their feelings.
Why would it be fun to have a pretend picnic with a friend?
Why is the math center a good place to count with a friend?
How can you show a feelingwith your markers?
Can you use clay to make the face of someone who feels very excited? How does the mouth look? How do the eyes look?
Can you find the letter Xx that you hear in the word excited?
How can you use blocks to make a playhouse for a little brother or sister?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. My BIG Feelings: In Five Small Tales by Sidney Hall, illustrated by Laura Watson. Copyright © 2018 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.Photo © HeinzTeh/Shutterstock.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: If You’re Happy and You Know It

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about feelings and to introduce vocabulary (scared, surprised).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts If You’re Happy and You Know It and My Big Feelings.
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to compare and contrast.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Write own name.
Identify emotions in self.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Discuss the idea that children are happy when they help.
Have children identify what is happening ina scene and why the child is happy, and act them out.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find pictures of two people? Compare the feelings they show.
Use kitchen tools to pretendto make a snack thatwould help a sad friendfeel better.
Draw three happy animalsand put them in order from happy to happiest.
Can you draw a picture of a favorite book you would share with a friend?
Can you use crayons or markers to make happy faces? Find the happiest face.
What letters do you like best? Draw them in the sand.
Can you try to build something that you have never built before, even if it’s hard to do?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. My BIG Feelings: In Five Small Tales by Sidney Hall, illustrated by Laura Watson. Copyright © 2018 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to act out scenes that show feelings and to introduce vocabulary (share).
Begin Story Time by revisiting My Big Feelings and asking, How do we show our feelings?
Read and retell interactively.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share and repeat the details in a text.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Write own name.
Identify emotions in self.
Engage in conflict resolution.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: How can you ask for help if you are feeling upset?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s work to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Which child in the story we read this week would you like to meet?
With a friend, can you act out how you help each other feel better?
Pretend your friend is sad. Can you play a counting activity with him to cheer him up?
Imagine that you went to a special place. Can you draw one exciting thing that you saw?
Make a two-part picture. Show a sad face and a happy face.
Invent a silly word that names a special feeling. Spell it out with letters. Tell a friend what your silly word means.
Can you design a happy city?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. My BIG Feelings: In Five Small Tales by Sidney Hall, illustrated by Laura Watson. Copyright © 2018 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Recognize that text has meaning.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors
Communicate basic emotions/feelings.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Recognize that text has meaning.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors
Communicate basic emotions/feelings.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Recognize that text has meaning.
Discuss and contribute ideas for drafts composed in whole- /small-group writing activities.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors
Communicate basic emotions/feelings.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Recognize that text has meaning.
Write own name (first name or frequent nickname) using legible letters in proper sequence.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors
Communicate basic emotions/feelings.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, moving to rhythms.
Retell or re-enact a story after it is read aloud.
Recognize that text has meaning.
Write own name (first name or frequent nickname) using legible letters in proper sequence.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors
Communicate basic emotions/feelings.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
